race.name: Glenwood Gravel
race.tagline: Iowa's original gravel series race, 30 minutes from Omaha through rolling western Iowa farmland.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Iowa countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Iowa event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Glenwood Gravel is a local event in Iowa—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Iowa countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Iowa gravel race. Worth it for Iowa/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Iowa—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Iowa races: Trans Iowa, Spotted Horse Ultra.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Glenwood has limited lodging options. Book ahead.
logistics.food: Glenwood has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Iowa rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Registration through BikeReg.com with standard options. The race promises they're "rethinking what a gravel race might be if you decided to race around your own home" for 2025 with "some surprise, but with all the good stuff still there." Research lacks parking and packet pickup specifics.

length.explanation: 62 miles hits the sweet spot for gravel racing - long enough to separate the field but short enough for recreational riders. Lucas Barloon won in 2:41:34 while back-of-pack finishers needed over 7 hours, showing the distance demands respect without requiring expedition planning. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Course runs through the Loess Hills with "moderate terrain with rolling short steep hills or moderate, sustained climbs." Organizers created a 2020 pre-race recon video to give racers "the inside track on course features," though dirt roads were "freshly graded" that year. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 2,400 feet over 62 miles through the Loess Hills region provides steady work without knockout punches. The terrain features "challenging" rolling hills and "moderate, sustained climbs" that test fitness more than technical handling skills. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 86°F and lows of 68°F, with a 37% chance of rain on any given day. August in Iowa brings heat and humidity challenges, though 2020 conditions were ideal at 67 degrees with 17 mph winds. 7:30 AM start time helps beat the worst heat, but that's not typical for Iowa summers. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Glenwood sits in Iowa farmland barely above sea level. Zero altitude considerations, zero acclimatization needed. Your sea-level fitness transfers directly without any thin-air complications. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Race markets itself as "the one that started it all" for the Iowa Gravel Series, promising to "make this a great day in the saddle for everyone." Located less than 30 minutes from Omaha through pastoral Iowa scenery, but not epic adventure territory.

prestige.explanation: Described as the founding race of the Iowa Gravel Series when Chris McQueen "put on the Glenwood Gravel Grinder and decided to expand" into seven races. Regional status in Iowa racing but not drawing national talent or media attention.

race_quality.explanation: Provides chip timing, marked course, aid stations, pro photography, and medical support. The Superbloom women's event at the same location advertised "More volunteers than you've probably ever seen at a local race," indicating strong organizational infrastructure.

experience.explanation: Event photography included with aid station snacks and medical support. Strong team culture visible with creative names like "Perineum Punishers" and "Team Struggle Bus." 85 finishers in 2020 showed solid participation for a regional Iowa event.

community.explanation: Exceptional team participation including Team Struggle Bus, Cycling Sloths, and "Perineum Punishers." Part of a seven-race Iowa series that builds season-long engagement. Race aims "to make this a great day in the saddle for everyone" with strong inclusive culture.

field_depth.explanation: Lucas Barloon's 2:41:34 win led a field ranging to 7:26+ finish times with median around 4 hours. 85 finishers in 2020 represents solid regional Iowa participation but August timing isn't drawing national competitive depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Single race entry starts at $40 early registration for chip timing, aid stations, and photography. The $399 full season pass covering seven races plus meals and gear makes excellent financial sense for Iowa series participants.

expenses.explanation: Glenwood, Iowa keeps lodging and dining costs reasonable compared to destination races. Located less than 30 minutes from Omaha provides accommodation options. Late registration bumps to $60-70 depending on package selection. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

citations.label: welovecycling.com: Gravel Queens Why Women Are Owning The Gravel Scene In 2025

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
